questions.question: Why were all kinds of people fighting in the street in the beginning of the play?

choices.answer: The Capulet dudes insulted the Montague dudes.
The Montague dudes insulted the Capulet dudes.
The sky was falling.
Bevolio was all like, "Tybalt, you're dumb!"

questions.question: What is the Prince going to do to anyone who fights in the street again?

choices.answer: Bannishment
Flogging
Jail time
Death

questions.question: Who is the girl Romeo is pining over at the beginning?

choices.answer: Juliet
Roselie
Diana
Rosaline

questions.question: Why can't Romeo dance at the party?

choices.answer: He's depressed over his "love."
He's too busy fighting Tybalt.
He stubbed his big toe.
Capulet and he are having a conversation.

questions.question: How does Tybalt know that Romeo has crashed the party?

choices.answer: Romeo's mask slips.
Romeo challenges Tybalt to a duel.
Tybalt hears Romeo's voice.
Tybalt is just guessing.

questions.question: Why won't Capulet let Tyablt fight Romeo?

choices.answer: Capulet doesn't want Tybalt to get into trouble (dead).
Capulet just wants to have fun (kinda like girls).
Tyablt is drunk and will lose to Romeo.
Capulet tells Tybalt to wait until later.

questions.question: How does Tyablt make it clear that revenge is in his mind?

choices.answer: Tybalt says he's so angry that he's shaking.
Tybalt says that he's going to get revenge.
Tybalt remarks on Romeo's mockery.
Capulet tells Tybalt that he should duel Romeo.

questions.question: How does Mercutio attempt to "conjure" Romeo?

choices.answer: He utters magic words and throws some dust.
He call Romeo by  many magic names.
He calls upon the powers of Cupid and Venus.
Mercutio calls Romeo forth with a description of Rosaline.

questions.question: Juliet says, "What's in a name? That which we call a rose...". What does Juliet mean by this?

choices.answer: Romeo is sweet and beautiful like a rose.
Romeo's name is unimportant to her love.
Romeo brought her flowers, so he's not so bad.
Juliet thinks that Romeo's name is stupid.

questions.question: Why doesn't Juliet want Romeo to make any vows concerning their love?

choices.answer: Their love is too fleeting and quick like lightning.
Their love is too passionate like lightning.
Their love is bright and lovely like the sun
Juliet is afraid that Romeo doesn't really love her.

questions.question: Why do Romeo and Juliet commit to marriage right away?

choices.answer: They are afraid that their families will keep them apart.
The capulets want Paris to marry Juliet.
Their feelings are so strong that they don't need to wait.
The Montagues want Romeo to marry Diana.

questions.question: Why does the friar describe the sunrise and elements of nature?

choices.answer: He's talking about new life.
Flowers are symbols for love.
Nature is a metaphor for healing and life.
There are no sets or scenery on the Elizabethan stage.

questions.question: The Friar freaks out on Romeo for his new love. What might this mean about Romeo's love?

choices.answer: Romeo's love is impetuous and may be doubted.
Romeo's love is sincere and passionate.
Romeo's love for Rosaline isn't dead; he's just rebounding.
Juliet is not a real person; Romeo is going crazy.

questions.question: According to the friar, why didn't Rosaline return Romeo's love?

choices.answer: Rosaline wants to be a nun.
Romeo didn't love her because he doesn't know what love is.
Rosaline thinks that Romeo is ugly.
Rosaline is secretly interested in Mercutio.

questions.question: Why is Friar Laurence willing to marry Romeo and Juliet?

choices.answer: He thinks that Romeo really loves Juliet.
He knows that Romeo is rebounding, but doesn't care.
He realy doesn't want to marry them but has no choice.
He thinks their marriage will end the feud.

questions.question: What does Mercutio think was the real reason behind Romeo's love for Rosaline?

choices.answer: He thinks that it's true devotion.
He thinks that Romeo is obsessed with Rosaline.
He thinks that Romeo doesn't know what real love is.
He thinks that Romeo just wants to sleep with Rosaline.

questions.question: In Act II, scene 4, the Nurse brings up rosemary. Why is this an example of foreshadowing?

choices.answer: The rosemary means that they will get married.
The flower shows how obsessed they are with each other.
The flower is a symbol for love.
The flower is a symbol for remembering the dead.

questions.question: How is the Nurse delaying telling Juliet about her talk with Romeo dramatic irony?

choices.answer: Juliet didn't not expect to marry Romeo.
The audience knows that Romeo wants to marry Juliet.
The Nurse's inattention makes the auidence laugh.
The Nurse doesn't mean anything she says.

questions.question: How will Juliet sneak out to meet up with and marry Romeo?

choices.answer: She will climb down the ladder out of her window.
She will go to confession.
She will take a potion of invisibility and go out the front.
She will dress up like her nurse,

questions.question: What is the best reason for why Romeo will not listen to the Friar to be cautious in his love?

choices.answer: He thinks the Friar is a bumbling, old fool.
He doesn't get that the Friar has been there and done that.
He will listen to the Friar since the dude's smart.
He's impetuous and doesn't think about the consequences.

questions.question: Mercutio says that Benvolio likes to fight. How do we know that Mercutio's kidding?

choices.answer: Benvoilio is afraid to fight, so he avoids it.
Benvolio keeps from fighting Tybalt by speaking calmly.
He fights Tybalt and almost loses.
He breaks up the fight amoung the Montague and Capulet men.

questions.question: Why is Mercutio so angry that Romeo ignores Tybalt's insult?

choices.answer: He thinks that Romeo is being a coward.
He thinks that Romeo's love for Juliet is making him soft.
He thinks that Romeo didn't hear Tybalt.
He thinks that Romeo should defend hs honor.

questions.question: Mercutio says, "A plague o' both your houses". How is this an example of foreshadowing?

choices.answer: At the end of the play, everyone dies.
Romeo and Juliet's death ends the feud.
Both houses catch the plague.
Romeo and Juliet's deaths end both houses.

questions.question: Why does the Prince only banish Romeo instead of having him killed?

choices.answer: Romeo was avenging Mercutio's death.
Romeo tried to stop the fight in the first place.
Romeo didn't mean to kill Tybalt.
Mercutio's last words were to beg pardon for Romeo.

questions.question: When the Nurse tells Juliet of Tybalt's death, what literary technique is being used?

choices.answer: Verbal irony
Situational irony
Dramatic illusion
Dramatic irony

questions.question: How does Juliet first react to the news that Romeo killed Tybalt?

choices.answer: Juliet is furious with Tybalt for trying to kill Romeo.
Juliet is furious with Romeo for killing Tybalt.
Juliet falls down in a dead faint and hits her head.
Juliet slaps her nurse for insulting Romeo.

questions.question: Why does Juliet change her mind about Romeo after the nurse says, "Shame on Romeo"?

choices.answer: Juliet realizes that her loyalty must  be to her husband.
Juliet realizes that Tybalt was likely trying to kill Romeo.
Juliet realizes that Romeo is bad news and agrees.
Juliet agrees and says that Romeo is beautiful but evil.

questions.question: Both the Nurse and the Friar tell Romeo to be a man.What does this say about his personality?

choices.answer: Romeo is sensative and easily offended.
Romeo is emotional and subdued.
Romeo is sensative and emotional.
Romeo is emotional and dramatic.

questions.question: Why is Capulet pushing for Juliet to marry Paris on Thursday?

choices.answer: Keeping Juliet from Paris is cruel.
Capulet thinks that Juliet likes Paris.
Capulet needs the money, and he's trying to win a bet.
Capulet could use the money and life is really short.

questions.question: Which expression from scene 5 is an example of foreshadowing?

choices.answer: “...I see thee now...As one dead in the bottom of a tomb”
“Oh,thinkst thou weshall ever meet again?”
“Find thou the means, and I’ll find such a man”
“...I never shall be satisfied / With Romeo..."

questions.question: Why does the Nurse challenge Capulet when she has no right to interfere?

choices.answer: She doesn't like Capulet and thinks he's a thug.
She thinks he's being unfair.
Capulet has no right to yell at his daughter!
She won't let anyone hurt her "baby"

questions.question: How is marriage conflict between the Capulets and Juliet and example of dramatic irony?

choices.answer: We know Juliet is really mourning Romeo's leaving.
We know thatJuliet is already married to Romeo.
We know that Juliet is going to the Friar for help.
We know that Juliet is going to run away to Mantua & Roemo.

questions.question: Why is Capulet shocked and angry when Juliet refuses to marry Paris?

choices.answer: He thinks that Juliet is too stuck up.
He thinks that Juliet is not proud of the match
He thinks that she's ungrateful and doesn't care.
Capulet assumed that Juliet would capitulate to his demands.

questions.question: What does the Nurse’s advice say about her character?

choices.answer: She's mercenary, looking out for herself.
She's intelligent and calculating.
She's flighty and changes her mind easily.
She's constant and unflinching in the face of great trouble.

questions.question: Why does Juliet decide to go to Friar Laurence for help and advice?

choices.answer: because the Nurse wasn’t any help
because the Nurse doesnt know anything
because he can cleanse her of her sins
because he 's religious and knows her promblem

questions.question: Paris acts as if they are already married. What do his actions and words indicate about him?

choices.answer: He's possessive, arrogant, rich who wants a pretty wife.
He's kind, thoughtful and wants the best for his wife-to-be.
He's domineering.
He's self-deluded and thinks that Juliet actually likes him.

questions.question: For how many hours will Juliet be in her death-sleep?
In Act 5, scene 2, how does Shakespeare increase the pace of the plot even further?

choices.answer: Juliet and the Friar work out their potion plan.
Capulet move the wedding up a day
Lady Capulet says the wedding is fine on Thursday.
Juliet takes the sleeping potion.

questions.question: What effect does the scene 2 plot increase have on the ending?

choices.answer: Lady Capulet's arguing makes Capulet move the wedding up.
Juliet appears dead and the house is crazy with grief.
Juliet might die from the Friar's potion.
Juliet has to take the potion a day early.

questions.question: What impact does Peter and the musician’s conversation have on the audience after the “death”?

choices.answer: It is confusing and heightens the feeling of loss and grief.
It attempts to be a treatise on life, death, and laughter.
It uses humor to break the tension after the tragic scene.
It uses humor to show how much everyone really loves Juliet.

questions.question: What is the message conveyed by having the funny scene right after the tragic one?

choices.answer: Life still goes on in the midst of tragedy.
Shakespeare was bi-polar and liked to confuse people.
Laughing at death and sadness is a good coping method.
There is no message; it keeps the play from being sad.

questions.question: What is ironic about the line, “Beauty’s ensign yet/Is crimson in thy lips and in thy cheeks.”

choices.answer: Romeo dropped acid and is hallucinating. Juliet’s not there.
Romeo's in love, but Juliet really looks pale and lifeless.
Juliet's wearing make-up.
His description makes it obvious that Juliet is not dead.

questions.question: What are Romeo’s major tragic flaws that essentially led to his untimely, self-murder?

choices.answer: Romeo was too emotional, sensitive, and flighty.
Romeo was too rash, impetuous, and impulsive.
Romeo was too dramatic, gregarious, and exaggerated.
Romeo was too timid, demure, and reticent.

questions.question: What are Juliet’s major tragic flaws that essentially led to her untimely, self-murder?

choices.answer: Her naïveté and willingness to go along with Romeo
She was too emotional, dramatic, and never used her head.
She never thought for herself.
She didn't take the right advice.
